description: Digital Forensic Investigator guides you through the process of performing a forensic investigation and is for someone who is going to be doing corporate or criminal investigations that may include collecting, preserving and analyzing evidence and getting it ready to be presented in court. Viewers will learn the steps involved in performing an investigation, from securing the crime scene, to collecting and processing the evidence, and reporting the findings and hear about some of the certifications one can achieve to prove their knowledge in this area, which is important knowledge for all IT security personnel, giving you the knowledge needed to respond properly in the event of a security incident.
name: Digital Forensic Investigator
subtitle: Information retrieval and protection

episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,072
[SOUND] Welcome everybody to our

2
00:00:05,072 --> 00:00:11,906
digital forensic investigator series.

3
00:00:11,906 --> 00:00:13,901
I'm Mike Rodrick and with me today is Mr.

4
00:00:13,901 --> 00:00:17,606
Sean Oriyano, and we wanna give you
a heads up on what we're gonna be covering

5
00:00:17,606 --> 00:00:20,230
in our digital forensic
investigator series.

6
00:00:20,230 --> 00:00:23,330
And probably, Sean, the first thing we
need to talk about is who the heck is

7
00:00:23,330 --> 00:00:24,762
a digital forensic investigator?

8
00:00:24,762 --> 00:00:28,622
Who's gonna be interested in taking or
watching these episodes?

9
00:00:28,622 --> 00:00:29,493
>> That's a great question.

10
00:00:29,493 --> 00:00:32,043
Because we wanna really kinda
pin down who the audience is and

11
00:00:32,043 --> 00:00:34,240
talk about what a forensic
investigator is.

12
00:00:34,240 --> 00:00:38,110
So, briefly, a forensic investigator is
gonna be someone who's doing corporate or

13
00:00:38,110 --> 00:00:42,360
criminal investigations, collecting,
preserving and analyzing evidence, and

14
00:00:42,360 --> 00:00:46,650
getting it ready to be presented in court,
if need be.

15
00:00:46,650 --> 00:00:51,600
They may be presenting it or someone
else may be presenting it, who will

16
00:00:51,600 --> 00:00:56,690
serve as the expert witness, but either
way, it's gonna kind of address that.

17
00:00:56,690 --> 00:01:00,210
You are gonna be running processes,
procedures for one of those two areas.

18
00:01:00,210 --> 00:01:02,635
>> So, we're gonna be like
CSI in the digital world,

19
00:01:02,635 --> 00:01:03,310
that's what you're telling me.

20
00:01:03,310 --> 00:01:06,755
We're gonna be going out there and
investigating these crime scenes, where

21
00:01:06,755 --> 00:01:10,359
people have used computers to make some
kind of attack against other computers or

22
00:01:10,359 --> 00:01:12,320
to forge something or something like that.

23
00:01:12,320 --> 00:01:16,189
And it's gonna be up to us, the digital
forensic investigator to capture that

24
00:01:16,189 --> 00:01:20,055
information, find all that evidence
they've done so much to try to hide, and

25
00:01:20,055 --> 00:01:22,714
then bring it into court and
prosecute those people.

26
00:01:22,714 --> 00:01:26,172
>> Yeah, once we get into the real
meat of this whole thing,

27
00:01:26,172 --> 00:01:31,210
you'll see how varied the crime is that
you could be expected to investigate.

28
00:01:31,210 --> 00:01:34,820
It could be denial of service type stuff,
it could actually be terrorism,

29
00:01:34,820 --> 00:01:36,850
it could be something as mundane, maybe,

30
00:01:36,850 --> 00:01:40,820
as violating corporate policy,
it could be someone creating malware.

31
00:01:40,820 --> 00:01:42,060
Forensics, for example,

32
00:01:42,060 --> 00:01:45,890
played a big role in catching the author
of the Melissa virus years ago.

33
00:01:45,890 --> 00:01:49,653
That was a big part of that, so there's
some big cases that have this has played

34
00:01:49,653 --> 00:01:53,204
a big role in, and there's a whole
bunch of other ones behind the scenes.

35
00:01:53,204 --> 00:01:57,120
But, this is a really exciting and
developing field, kind of being able to

36
00:01:57,120 --> 00:02:01,015
lift the lid and peek in, and
see what's hidden underneath the surface.

37
00:02:01,015 --> 00:02:01,650
>> Heck, yeah.

38
00:02:01,650 --> 00:02:04,000
This is the cool part of security.

39
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:08,300
So, in our course, we're going
to cover a gamut of information.

40
00:02:08,300 --> 00:02:12,520
All the way from going to the crime scene,
collecting the evidence,

41
00:02:12,520 --> 00:02:15,480
preserving the evidence,
processing that evidence.

42
00:02:15,480 --> 00:02:19,090
And then, turn it into some kind of
deliverable, that we can take in the end,

43
00:02:19,090 --> 00:02:21,655
either us or whoever has to go to court.

44
00:02:21,655 --> 00:02:25,117
So, what kind of information are we
gonna learn watching these episodes?

45
00:02:25,117 --> 00:02:28,145
>> We've got tons for you in this course.

46
00:02:28,145 --> 00:02:30,535
We'll be learning technical information,

47
00:02:30,535 --> 00:02:33,570
probably deeper technical
information than you've had before.

48
00:02:33,570 --> 00:02:36,800
We'll be doing some things that you
probably didn't think were possible,

49
00:02:36,800 --> 00:02:38,320
just to recover evidence.

50
00:02:38,320 --> 00:02:39,980
We'll figure those ones out.

51
00:02:39,980 --> 00:02:42,520
We'll be doing that in the hardware,
we'll be doing that in software.

52
00:02:42,520 --> 00:02:45,280
Then, we'll be figuring out,
once we learn those procedures,

53
00:02:45,280 --> 00:02:47,820
also be talking about
how you can collect it.

54
00:02:47,820 --> 00:02:51,650
Cuz you just can't go through and scoop
something up and say here, it's evidence.

55
00:02:51,650 --> 00:02:53,470
It has to be collected a certain way.

56
00:02:53,470 --> 00:02:55,620
And has to be documented a certain way.

57
00:02:55,620 --> 00:02:58,610
And then,
when we put that on the table and

58
00:02:58,610 --> 00:03:01,760
we sprinkle some other stuff on
top of it which has to go there,

59
00:03:01,760 --> 00:03:05,590
that's the legal procedures which may not
be the most exciting things, granted.

60
00:03:05,590 --> 00:03:08,210
But it's something that you
do have to also address.

61
00:03:08,210 --> 00:03:11,710
Something like federal rules of evidence,
and local and

62
00:03:11,710 --> 00:03:13,598
state laws wherever possible.

63
00:03:13,598 --> 00:03:15,180
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don't worry we're not going to turn you

64
00:03:15,180 --> 00:03:15,772
into a lawyer.

65
00:03:15,772 --> 00:03:18,606
But there's gonna be a lot of
neat stuff here to cover and

66
00:03:18,606 --> 00:03:20,850
some stuff that you'll find interesting.

67
00:03:20,850 --> 00:03:22,011
Warrants, stuff like that.

68
00:03:22,011 --> 00:03:23,830
>> It really is fascinating.

69
00:03:23,830 --> 00:03:25,290
And it's extremely important.

70
00:03:25,290 --> 00:03:30,080
Because when we talk about cyber crimes,
or if somebody is doing something illegal

71
00:03:30,080 --> 00:03:33,860
using computers, as you said, we wanna
be able to prosecute them in the end.

72
00:03:33,860 --> 00:03:35,160
That's the whole goal.

73
00:03:35,160 --> 00:03:38,120
And I can't just go in there blindly,
like you said, and go, oh,

74
00:03:38,120 --> 00:03:38,950
here's their computer.

75
00:03:38,950 --> 00:03:40,960
And I'm gonna start opening up Windows and

76
00:03:40,960 --> 00:03:44,780
looking at log files and searching their
hard drive for files and things like that.

77
00:03:44,780 --> 00:03:47,125
And at that point,
I have pretty much ruined everything, and

78
00:03:47,125 --> 00:03:49,530
we're probably never gonna be
able to prosecute that person.

79
00:03:49,530 --> 00:03:55,100
>> Here, let me just kind of build on
something he said here and kinda show you.

80
00:03:55,100 --> 00:03:59,803
One of the things that, it's not to
pick on you or anything about it.

81
00:03:59,803 --> 00:04:00,870
>> It's okay, you can pick on me.

82
00:04:00,870 --> 00:04:01,438
>> I'm going to pick on him.

83
00:04:01,438 --> 00:04:04,310
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we got two weeks of that.

84
00:04:04,310 --> 00:04:05,580
>> It's a good thing I
got thick skin [LAUGH].

85
00:04:05,580 --> 00:04:07,200
>> So,
we're just going to work up from here.

86
00:04:08,310 --> 00:04:13,730
But one of the things that is a common
thing to think about forensics

87
00:04:13,730 --> 00:04:17,130
which we're gonna learn differently is
you may not take it to actual court,

88
00:04:17,130 --> 00:04:19,200
you may not be prosecuting someone.

89
00:04:19,200 --> 00:04:24,020
You may actually be working
inside a corporation that may be

90
00:04:24,020 --> 00:04:28,000
collecting evidence because they need to
say, hey, this person violated policy,

91
00:04:28,000 --> 00:04:31,510
we've got the paperwork to back it up and
you're outta here.

92
00:04:31,510 --> 00:04:36,290
And maybe, just for that, but
it doesn't mean because you're

93
00:04:36,290 --> 00:04:39,520
just letting someone go out of a company
doesn't mean there's a lesser standard.

94
00:04:39,520 --> 00:04:43,210
That person that you let go could say,
well, heck with you, I didn't do that,

95
00:04:43,210 --> 00:04:44,240
I'm gonna sue you.

96
00:04:44,240 --> 00:04:45,280
Now, you're going to court.

97
00:04:45,280 --> 00:04:48,660
So, you still have to collect it,
and along the same lines but

98
00:04:48,660 --> 00:04:50,510
you may not be prosecuting it.

99
00:04:50,510 --> 00:04:53,040
>> Gotcha.
>> Just to kind of give you a peek of some

100
00:04:53,040 --> 00:04:56,090
of the things that might actually
change your way of thinking.

101
00:04:56,090 --> 00:04:58,555
>> And
that's why we've got the expert here.

102
00:04:58,555 --> 00:04:59,483
[LAUGH]
>> Bam!

103
00:04:59,483 --> 00:05:00,640
[LAUGH]
>> So,

104
00:05:00,640 --> 00:05:02,539
Sean we've got a bunch
of great information,

105
00:05:02,539 --> 00:05:04,870
we're gonna be going
over in these episodes.

106
00:05:04,870 --> 00:05:07,910
In the end,
we might wanna get certified as well.

107
00:05:07,910 --> 00:05:11,730
We might wanna be able to prove what we
know so that we can go out and get a job,

108
00:05:11,730 --> 00:05:13,350
if we're not already employed.

109
00:05:13,350 --> 00:05:15,720
Maybe, we wanna go get a job or
maybe you wanna change fields and

110
00:05:15,720 --> 00:05:19,705
get into this really exciting forensic
investigator's type lifestyle.

111
00:05:19,705 --> 00:05:23,165
So, there's a couple certifications
we might be able to obtain with

112
00:05:23,165 --> 00:05:25,825
a little setting and
watching these episodes.

113
00:05:25,825 --> 00:05:28,475
>> Yes, there are a couple of
certifications that really just kind of

114
00:05:28,475 --> 00:05:29,865
jump out at you,

115
00:05:29,865 --> 00:05:33,530
because there's a whole kind of a sea
of forensic certifications really.

116
00:05:33,530 --> 00:05:35,955
There are different specialties and
all it in there.

117
00:05:35,955 --> 00:05:39,940
But the two that come to mind for
taking this particular course

118
00:05:39,940 --> 00:05:44,510
are EC-Council Computer Hacking
Forensic Investigator and then,

119
00:05:44,510 --> 00:05:48,070
there's also ISC squared,
the people that do the CISSP.

120
00:05:48,070 --> 00:05:52,464
They also have one called CCFP, which
is some alphabet soup which stands for,

121
00:05:52,464 --> 00:05:54,137
putting Mike on the spot now.

122
00:05:54,137 --> 00:05:56,996
>> Certified Cyber Forensic Professional.

123
00:05:56,996 --> 00:05:59,480
Certified Cyber Forensic Professional.

124
00:05:59,480 --> 00:06:01,310
If I can say that one word.

125
00:06:01,310 --> 00:06:02,680
So, yeah,
a couple of great certifications.

126
00:06:02,680 --> 00:06:04,520
Think that,
you can watch these episodes and

127
00:06:04,520 --> 00:06:06,520
you could walk out of here
with two certifications.

128
00:06:06,520 --> 00:06:09,060
Many letters to put behind your name.

129
00:06:09,060 --> 00:06:11,940
I've got some information pulled up here
on my screen, if we wanna look at it.

130
00:06:11,940 --> 00:06:18,425
The EC Council, again, puts on the
Computer Hacking Forensic Investigator.

131
00:06:18,425 --> 00:06:22,722
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's their exam number, 312-49.

132
00:06:22,722 --> 00:06:25,393
They're currently on
version 8 of that exam.

133
00:06:25,393 --> 00:06:29,900
And you can see here on my screen, it's
gonna be a test of about 150 questions.

134
00:06:29,900 --> 00:06:33,310
It's primarily multiple choice and
you're gonna need to get a 70% or

135
00:06:33,310 --> 00:06:36,672
greater to pass that exam and
get that certification.

136
00:06:36,672 --> 00:06:38,970
They're gonna give you four
hours to take that exam.

137
00:06:38,970 --> 00:06:40,702
So, plenty of time to get through there.

138
00:06:40,702 --> 00:06:44,240
And there's several different vendors
you can go through to take that exam.

139
00:06:44,240 --> 00:06:47,380
You've got Prometric Prime,
which is there online.

140
00:06:47,380 --> 00:06:51,420
So, if I don't have an authorized testing
center, I might be able to take it through

141
00:06:51,420 --> 00:06:54,930
Prometric Prime, where I've got just,
what do you call it, proctor.

142
00:06:54,930 --> 00:06:58,370
Somebody that's gonna proctor the exam,
and I can take it on any computer.

143
00:06:58,370 --> 00:07:01,720
They also offer it, of course,
through their authorized test centers.

144
00:07:01,720 --> 00:07:05,630
With the Prometric test
centers as well as VUE, so

145
00:07:05,630 --> 00:07:09,650
if the test center in your area is Pearson
VUE, you can take it through there.

146
00:07:09,650 --> 00:07:11,530
The cost for the exam is a little steep.

147
00:07:11,530 --> 00:07:13,996
It's gonna be $500 for that exam,

148
00:07:13,996 --> 00:07:18,080
plus you're gonna have to
pay a $100 application fee.

149
00:07:18,080 --> 00:07:20,360
So, once you're ready, you've studied,

150
00:07:20,360 --> 00:07:23,760
you've got the information you need,
you go to EC Council's website,

151
00:07:23,760 --> 00:07:26,859
you fill out an application,
you send them in 100 bucks,

152
00:07:26,859 --> 00:07:32,060
they're gonna send you back a voucher that
you can then go use and take that exam.

153
00:07:32,060 --> 00:07:33,240
So, that's the EC council,

154
00:07:33,240 --> 00:07:36,710
that's the computer hacking forensic
investigator certification.

155
00:07:36,710 --> 00:07:40,700
Also, you might be interested
in taking the ISC squared exam

156
00:07:40,700 --> 00:07:44,550
which is their brand new one,
the Certified Cyber Forensic Professional.

157
00:07:44,550 --> 00:07:47,390
Very similar,
as far as the test breakdown goes.

158
00:07:47,390 --> 00:07:52,400
Another four hours for that exam,
about 125 questions on this one.

159
00:07:52,400 --> 00:07:55,060
Again, multiple choice type questions.

160
00:07:55,060 --> 00:08:00,220
You need to get a 700 or a 70% out
of 1000 points to pass that exam.

161
00:08:00,220 --> 00:08:01,140
And what else?

162
00:08:01,140 --> 00:08:04,612
Oh, the cost for that one is $549.

163
00:08:04,612 --> 00:08:06,438
So, you can see, there pretty comparable.

164
00:08:06,438 --> 00:08:08,900
>> Imagine, two four hour exams.

165
00:08:08,900 --> 00:08:10,020
>> I know, you can spend all day.

166
00:08:10,020 --> 00:08:11,360
>> Get the kids a baby sitter.

167
00:08:11,360 --> 00:08:11,912
You're gonna be busy.

168
00:08:11,912 --> 00:08:15,020
>> [LAUGH] You can definitely
spend all day in that booth, so

169
00:08:15,020 --> 00:08:18,150
you might wanna break that up to
separate days if you're gonna do it.

170
00:08:18,150 --> 00:08:20,180
Or heck, go all for it.

171
00:08:20,180 --> 00:08:21,590
Get in there and take them both.

172
00:08:21,590 --> 00:08:22,230
>> No, don't do that.

173
00:08:22,230 --> 00:08:24,350
>> Don't do that,
I'm just kidding with you.

174
00:08:24,350 --> 00:08:27,430
So, ladies and gentlemen,
I hope you guys are as excited as we are.

175
00:08:27,430 --> 00:08:31,635
Stay tuned, we've got our digital forensic
investigator series coming your way.

176
00:08:31,635 --> 00:08:37,334
[SOUND]
